0.text:
Uefa has fined the Football Association and the Football Association of Ireland after the national anthems were booed before the Republic of Ireland played England in the Nations League in September.

European football's governing body imposed a £10,500 fine (12,500 euros) on the Football Association (FA) following England fans' booing of Amhran na bhFiann at Aviva Stadium.

The Football Association of Ireland (FAI) received a fine of £8,400 (10,000 euros) after home supporters booed God Save The King.

The FA's punishment is greater because the England fans' booing was deemed a repeat offence.

Uefa imposed further punishment on the FAI, with a £7,800 (9,250 euros) fine for the lighting of flares and a £5,000 (6,000 euros) penalty for a pitch invasion by a spectator.

The FA was also fined £4,150 (5,000 euros) for a supporter coming on to the field of play.

England won the September 7 match 2-0 with goals from Jack Grealish and Declan Rice.

2.text:
Here is the translation of the text from French to English:

UEFA has imposed fines on the English Football Association and the Irish Football Association after the national anthems were booed before Ireland played England in the Nations League in September.

The governing body of football in Europe has imposed a fine of £10,500 (€12,500) on the English Football Association (FA) after English supporters booed Amhran na bhFiann at the Aviva Stadium.

The Irish Football Association (FAI) received a fine of £8,400 (€10,000) after home supporters booed God Save The King.

The FA's punishment is more severe as the English supporters' booing was considered a repeated offense.

UEFA has imposed additional punishment on the FAI, with a fine of £7,800 (€9,250) for the implementation of fireworks and a penalty of £5,000 (€6,000) for a spectator who invaded the pitch.

The FA was also fined £4,150 (€5,000) after one of the supporters entered the playing field.

England won the match on September 7 with a 2-0 score, with goals from Jack Grealish and Declan Rice.
